The '''[[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]]''', more commonly known as the '''Iran nuclear deal''' was the international agreement reached on [[Nuclear program of Iran|Iran's nuclear program]] in [[Vienna]] in 2015. The deal, made after several years of negotiation, set in place strict guidelines to regulate and oversee the Iranian nuclear program including the reduction of [[centrifuges]], [[enriched uranium]] stockpiles, and an agreement to allow regular inspections of nuclear sites, among other aspects. The deal has attracted enormous criticism by certain political and media elements in the [[United States]] and [[Iran]] as the deal is viewed as conciliatory in nature by some factions in both countries. For example, [[Donald Trump|President Donald J. Trump]] called the Iran deal, “the worst deal ever negotiated”<ref name="The Timez Editorial Board 2018">{{cite web | author=The Times Editorial Board | title=Trump is inching closer to blowing up the Iran nuclear deal | website=latimes.com | date=2018-01-13 | url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/editorials/la-ed-trump-iran-20180113-story.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> and United States [[Senate Majority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]] characterized it as "flawed",<ref name="MitchFlawed 2015">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=McConnell says Iran agreement flawed, promises thorough review | website=U.S. | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-congress-mcconnell/mcconnell-says-iran-agreement-flawed-promises-thorough-review-idUSKCN0PO1MT20150714 | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> while hardliners in Iran have indicated a desire to subvert it.<ref name="Erdbrinkz 2015">{{cite web | last=Erdbrink | first=Thomas | title=Iran Celebrates Nuclear Deal, Tempered by Cynicism and Hard-Liner Warnings | website=The New York Times | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/world/middleeast/iran-celebrates-nuclear-deal-tempered-by-cynicism-and-hard-liner-warnings.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Much of the criticism in the United States has been centered on the issue of appeasement and Iran's compliance, while in Iran many of the criticisms revolve around the issue of sovereignty and non-nuclear restrictions.<ref name="TIME.com 2013">{{cite web | title=Not Everyone’s Happy: Hardliners in Iran Criticize Geneva Nuclear Deal | website=TIME.com | date=2013-11-25 | url=http://world.time.com/2013/11/25/not-everyones-happy-hardliners-in-iran-criticize-geneva-nuclear-deal/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
In Iran, debate over the deal has become representative of a number of persisting social, economic, and political conflicts that have played a large role in the rift between [[moderates]], [[reformists]], and [[conservatives]].<ref name="Fisher 2016">{{cite web | last=Fisher | first=Max | title=How the nuclear deal boosted Iran's moderates - and showed Iranian elections can matter | website=Vox | date=2016-03-02 | url=https://www.vox.com/2016/3/2/11147102/iran-election-moderates-nuclear-deal | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> In the United States, the deal is seen as a symbol in the battle between competing visions on how the United States should carry out its [[United States foreign policy in the Middle East|foreign policy in the Middle East]].
==Background and content==
Negotiation on Iran's nuclear program between the international community and Iran have occurred on and off since 2006, however the negotiations that led to the 2015 framework agreement, and the eventual final agreement, began in March 2013.<ref name="Arms Control Association 2018">{{cite web | title=Timeline of Nuclear Diplomacy With Iran | website=Arms Control Association | date=2018-01-12 | url=https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheet/Timeline-of-Nuclear-Diplomacy-With-Iran | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> These talks, spearheaded by State Department officials [[Jake Sullivan]] and [[William Joseph Burns]], were conducted with an Iranian delegation led by Iranian Deputy Foreign Minister Ali Asghar Khaji.<ref name="Editorialz 2013">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=U.S., Iran held secret talks on march to nuclear deal | website=U.S. | date=2013-11-24 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-bilateral/u-s-iran-held-secret-talks-on-march-to-nuclear-deal-idUSBRE9AN0FB20131124 | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The initial meetings were largely fruitless but June 2013 saw the election of [[Hassan Rouhani]], a centrist and reformist from the [[Moderation and Development Party]]. Rouhani had previously served as [[Supreme National Security Council|Secretary of the Supreme National Security Council]] and as such had been Iran's lead nuclear negotiator as recently as 2005.<ref name="Naji 2017">{{cite web | last=Naji | first=Kasra | title=Profile: Hassan Rouhani | website=BBC News | date=2017-05-20 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-22886729 | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> At his inauguration in August 2013 and during a phone call with [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] in September 2013, Rouhani relayed his intent to restart negotiations with the West on the nuclear issue.<ref name="Al Jazeera 2017">{{cite web | title=At inauguration Hassan Rouhani urges more talks | website=Al Jazeera | date=2017-08-05 | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/inauguration-hassan-rouhani-urges-talks-170805130014403.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> By November 2013, the [[P5+1]] countries and Iran reached a pact known as the [[Joint Plan of Action]]. This interim agreement was signed in [[Geneva]] and included provisions that limited Iran's use of [[enriched uranium]], restricted the installation of new [[centrifuges]], and allowed [[IAEA]] supervision of several [[Nuclear facilities in Iran|Iranian nuclear sites]], all in exchange for modest sanctions relief by the United States. The plan was slated to go into effect in January 2014.<ref name="Washington Post JPAINTERIM">{{cite web | title=World powers reach nuclear deal with Iran to freeze its nuclear program | website=Washington Post | date=2013-11-23 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/kerry-in-geneva-raising-hopes-for-historic-nuclear-deal-with-iran/2013/11/23/53e7bfe6-5430-11e3-9fe0-fd2ca728e67c_story.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
Further negotiations between [[P5+1]] and Iran took place over the course of 2014 in pursuit of a more comprehensive deal. In June 2014, the deadline to meet the goal of a comprehensive agreement was not met and the deadline was therefore extended to November 2014. After the goal of November 2014 was not met, another extension was made to June 2015.<ref name="Lyons 2015">{{cite web | last=Lyons | first=Kate | title=Iran nuclear talks: timeline | website=the Guardian | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/02/iran-nuclear-talks-timeline | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
In April 2015, the negotiations produced a [[Iran nuclear deal framework|framework deal]] which included provisions for intensified inspections by the IAEA, and increased restrictions on the nuclear program.<ref name="Borger Lewis 2015FRAMEWORK">{{cite web | last=Borger | first=Julian | last2=Lewis | first2=Paul | title=Iran nuclear deal: negotiators announce 'framework' agreement | website=the Guardian | date=2015-04-02 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/02/iran-nuclear-deal-negotiators-announce-framework-agreement | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> The details of the plan were not worked out until negotiations of the plan concluded three months later. Talks over the specifics of the framework deal were carried out over the course of these three months primarily between [[United States|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[John Kerry]] and [[Foreign Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Mohammad Javad Zarif]] with the other foreign ministers of [[P5+1]] also taking part. On 14 July 2015, after seventeen days of near uninterrupted negotiations and a deadline extension, P5+1 and Iran reached a finalized agreement, the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]].<ref name="SeventeenDays 2015">{{cite web | last=Porter | first=Gareth | title=Behind the Scenes: How the US and Iran Reached Their Landmark Deal | website=The Nation | date=2015-09-05 | url=https://www.thenation.com/article/behind-the-scenes-how-the-us-and-iran-reached-their-landmark-deal/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
[[IAEA]] inspectors spend 3,000 calendar days per year in Iran, installing tamper-proof sealings and collecting surveillance camera photos, measurement data and documents. IAEA representatives asserted (e.g. in March 2018) that they have verified that Iran is implementing its nuclear-related commitments.<ref>[https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/statements/iaea-director-generals-introductory-remarks-at-press-conference IAWA director general Yukiya Amano: Introductory remarks at press conference], 5 March 2018</ref>
[[File:Arak Heavy Water4.JPG|thumbnail|left|Arak heavy water plant.]]
===Key provisions of the JCPOA===
*Reduction of Iran's stockpile of [[enriched uranium]] by 98%, from 10,000 kilograms to 300 kilograms, to be maintained over fifteen years. Remaining uranium will only be authorized to be enriched to 3.67%, the level adequate enough for use in civilian [[nuclear power]] and research. Existing enriched uranium above the 3.67% mark will be sold or diluted. All research and development into enriched uranium is limited for a period of eight years and may only be conducted at the [[Natanz#nuclear facility|Natanz nuclear facility]] in [[Isfahan Province|Isfahan Province, Iran]]. *An exhaustive system of inspections by international observers from the [[IAEA]] will be put in place. This system will include a continuous monitoring of all aspects of Iran's nuclear supply chain such as [[uranium]] mills, observation by [[infrared]] [[satellites]], [[fiber optic]] seals on equipment, sensors, and surveillance cameras. Dedicated IAEA inspectors for [[Iran]], will triple from 50 to 150. IAEA inspectors also have the ability to request physical access to sites if specific concerns of non-compliance arise. *Iran will cut down on the number of operational [[centrifuges]]. Of its 19,000 centrifuges, all but 6,104 will be put in storage with an even smaller amount allowed to enrich uranium for a period of ten years. All of the stored centrifuges must be held at the [[Natanz]] site under [[IAEA]] supervision. *Iran is forbidden from constructing additional heavy water sites or accumulating additional heavy water for a period of fifteen years. Iran's existing [[IR-40|Arak heavy water reactor site]] will be forbidden from producing power above 20 MWth (megawatt thermal) and will undergo a redesign to limit its capability to produce [[Reactor-grade plutonium|weapons grade plutonium]]. All heavy water in Iran's possession that exceeds the limitations of the deal will be placed for sale on the international market. *Iran will not participate in [[Nuclear reprocessing|spent fuel reprocessing]] in any capacity for a period of fifteen years and all [[Spent nuclear fuel|spent fuel]] in Iran will be shipped out of the country. *The [[Fordow Fuel Enrichment Plant]] will be forbidden from holding fissile material. Of the 2,700 IR-1 [[centrifuges]] currently installed at Fordow, only 1,044 will be allowed to remain. Enriching of uranium at the site will also be heavily restricted. *A "snapback" mechanism that automatically replaces all [[Sanctions against Iran|international sanctions on Iran]] if compliance of the agreement is not met.<ref name="Panda Diplomat 2015">{{cite web | last=Panda | first=Ankit | last2=Diplomat | first2=The | title=How the Iran Deal's 'Snap Back' Mechanism Will Keep Tehran Compliant | website=The Diplomat | date=2015-07-15 | url=https://thediplomat.com/2015/07/how-the-iran-deals-snap-back-mechanism-will-keep-tehran-compliant/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref name="whitehouse.gov 2015">{{cite web | title=Key Excerpts of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) | website=whitehouse.gov | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/the-press-office/2015/07/14/key-excerpts-joint-comprehensive-plan-action-jcpoa | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
==Controversial features==
===Sanctions relief===
The lifting of economic and military sanctions on [[Iran]] led to much ire among conservatives and some liberals in the [[United States]] who viewed the move as detrimental to security in the region.<ref name="ire 2015">{{cite web | title=Lawmakers alarmed over Iranian nuclear windfall | website=USA TODAY | date=2015-07-05 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2015/07/05/lawmakers-alarmed-iran-nuclear-windfall/29652429/ | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> The value of the money [[Iranian frozen assets|frozen in foreign banks]] that would become available to the regime upon the deal's implementation was estimated to be between $29 billion and $150 billion. Money that, critics claim, would lead to increasing expenditures on Iran's military capability and a financial boost to proxy groups in the region such as [[Hezbollah]] in [[Lebanon]] and [[Houthis|Houthi rebels]] in [[Yemen]]. The billions of dollars Iran would have access to was assailed as a "signing bonus" by some critics. However, the [[United States Department of the Treasury|Department of Treasury]] estimated that Iran's [[liquid assets]] after the sanctions relief would be only $50 billion, most of which would not go to military activities because of Iran's dire need for [[foreign reserves]].<ref name="Gladstoness 2015">{{cite web | last=Gladstone | first=Rick | title=Value of Iran Sanctions Relief Is Hard to Measure | website=The New York Times | date=2015-08-05 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/world/middleeast/conflicting-claims-cloud-irans-financial-gain-in-nuclear-deal.html | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
===Effect on Israel=== {{POV|date=January 2018}} Shortly after the announcement of the deal, critics within the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] and the [[Israel lobby in the United States]] lambasted the move as a rebuff to Israel and a blatant undermining of [[Israel-United States relations]]. In addition, the deal was characterized as a threat to Israel's national security on the basis that it would to lead to an empowerment of anti-Israel actors in the region and the deal would actually facilitate [[Iran's nuclear program]] rather than hamper it. [[Tom Cotton|Senator Tom Cotton]] (R-[[arkansas|AR]]) visited Israel and met with Israeli [[Benjamin Netanyahu|Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu]] shortly after the announcement of the deal and vocalized his commitment to Israel. Prior to the visit, Cotton has said his solution to Iran's nuclear program would be a “credible threat of military force”.<ref name="Washington Postzzz 2012">{{cite web | title=Tom Cotton: No ordinary freshman congressman | website=Washington Post | date=2012-12-05 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/right-turn/wp/2012/12/05/tom-cotton-no-ordinary-freshman-congressman/ | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref><ref name="Beinarzt 2015">{{cite web | last=Beinart | first=Peter | title=Why the Iran Deal Makes Obama's Critics So Angry | website=The Atlantic | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/07/iran-nuclear-deal-obama/398450/ | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
Benjamin Netanyahu, who called the Iran nuclear deal a "historic mistake", told [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] that Israel was under increased threat because of the deal and said in a statement, “In the coming decade, the deal will reward Iran, the terrorist regime in [[Tehran]], with hundreds of billions of dollars. This cash bonanza will fuel Iran’s terrorism worldwide, its aggression in the region and its efforts to destroy Israel, which are ongoing.”<ref name="Kershnerses 2015">{{cite web | last=Kershner | first=Isabel | title=Iran Deal Denounced by Netanyahu as ‘Historic Mistake’ | website=The New York Times | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/world/middleeast/iran-nuclear-deal-israel.html | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Many conservatives in the United States claimed the deal would usher a financial windfall for Iranian sponsored groups in the Middle East that pose a threat to Israel including [[Hezbollah]] and [[Hamas]]. In addition the lack of focus on Iran's ballistic missile program and the lifting of weapons embargoes was also viewed as a peril for Israel.<ref name="The Iran Primerss 2016">{{cite web | title=Republican and Democratic Platforms on Iran | website=The Iran Primer | date=2016-07-25 | url=http://iranprimer.usip.org/blog/2016/jul/25/republican-and-democratic-platforms-iran | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> [[Donald Trump|President Donald Trump]] criticized what he viewed as the deal's "near total silence on Iran's missile programs.”<ref name="JNi.Medias 2017">{{cite web | author=JNi.Media | title=Israel, Saudis, Applaud, Europe Condemns Republicans’ Interjecting Realism into Iran Nuke Deal - The Jewish Press - 25 Tishri 5778 – October 14, 2017 - JewishPress.com | website=JewishPress.com | date=2017-10-14 | url=http://www.jewishpress.com/news/us-news/israel-saudis-applaud-europe-condemns-republicans-interjecting-realism-into-iran-nuke-deal/2017/10/14/ | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
===Inspection regime===
Under the deal, international monitors are authorized to monitor declared Iranian nuclear sites through numerous electronic means including but not limited to: fiber-optic seals, cameras, sensors that detect radioactive particles, and commercial satellite imagery. President Obama said that [[IAEA]] inspectors would have "24/7 access" to Iran's "key nuclear facilities."<ref name="The New York Times 2015">{{cite web | title=Text and Video: Obama’s Address on the Iran Nuclear Deal | website=The New York Times | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/15/world/middleeast/text-and-video-obamas-address-on-the-iran-nuclear-deal.html | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Critics claimed that the inspection regime would not provide sufficient access to Iran's military sites. IAEA inspectors may request access to these sites if genuine concerns of non-compliance arise but it can take up to 24 days to resolve a dispute over an access request.<ref name="Kaplanese 2015">{{cite web | last=Kaplan | first=Rebecca | title=Obama says inspectors get access to "any" site in Iran. Is it true? | website=CBS News | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/obama-inspectors-access-any-site-iran-true/ | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Critics say this provision means that Iran would be able to covertly advance its nuclear ambitions while still abiding by the deal.<ref name="Lewis Siddiqui Jacobs 2015">{{cite web | last=Lewis | first=Paul | last2=Siddiqui | first2=Sabrina | last3=Jacobs | first3=Ben | title=Republicans fume over Iran nuclear deal but hope of undermining accord is slim | website=the Guardian | date=2015-07-15 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/14/republicans-iran-nuclear-deal-reaction | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Ali Vaez, Iran Project Director at the [[International Crisis Group]], said the deal ensured the international community had "better access to Iran's military sites" than ever before.<ref name="NPR.organs 2017">{{cite web | title=Access To Military Sites Debated As White House Reconsiders Iran Nuclear Deal | website=NPR.org | date=2017-09-13 | url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2017/09/13/549217764/should-nuclear-inspectors-be-demanding-access-to-irans-military-sites | access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref>
==Opposition in Iran== [[File:Protest against JCPOA during Ali Akbar Salehi speech in the Parliament.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Ali Akbar Salehi]], head of Iran's atomic energy agency, is heckled by anti-JCPOA members of the [[Islamic Consultative Assembly]].]] Iran was less bitterly divided over the deal than the United States but opposition in the form of hardliners, especially in more conservative religious institutions such as the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]] still existed. These hardliners are concentrated more in Iran's unelected governmental institutions such as the aforementioned Revolutionary Guards, the [[Basij]], the [[Assembly of Experts]], and the [[Guardian Council]]. These bodies wield immense power in the [[Islamic Republic of Iran|Islamic Republic]] and are composed largely of clerical elites and religious reactionaries who bitterly oppose the [[Western world|West]] and [[Western culture|Western ideals]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobepost.com/2018/05/01/iran-nuclear-talks-security/|title=Iran Deal: a Stepping Stone to Further Talks on Regional Security|last=Knott|first=Paul|date=2018-05-01|work=The Globe Post|access-date=2018-05-02|language=en-US}}</ref> Those more open to the deal included Iran's centrists and reformists who are characterized by a greater openness to foreign cultures, [[secularization]], and [[economic globalization]]. The JCPOA created a rift at the highest levels of government as evidenced by a leaked government directive to media outlets which urged them to praise the deal and its negotiators and avoid criticism.<ref name="Naji 2015">{{cite web |last=Naji |first=Kasra |title=Iranian press 'ordered to praise nuclear deal' |publisher=BBC News |date=2015-07-26 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-33668390 |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> [[File:Hassan Rouhani in Yazd 05.jpg|thumbnail|right|President [[Hassan Rouhani]]]] Iranian president [[Hassan Rouhani]], who in many ways paved the way for the deal, said the alternative to the deal was an "economic Stone Age" brought on by sanctions and economic isolation. He also chastised the Revolutionary Guard Corps for its opposition.<ref name="Erdbrink Gladstone 2015">{{cite web |last=Erdbrink |first=Thomas |last2=Gladstone |first2=Rick |title=Iran’s President Defends Nuclear Deal in Blunt Remarks |website=The New York Times |date=2015-07-23 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/24/world/middleeast/irans-president-defends-nuclear-deal-in-blunt-remarks.html |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Supreme Leader]] [[Ali Khamenei]] gave his tacit approval of the deal and characterized it as a win for Iran exclaiming, “After 12 years of struggling with the Islamic republic, the result is that they have to bear the turning of thousands of centrifuges in the country,” a move that is likely to quell the resistance of the country's hardliner factions.<ref name="Erdbrink 2015">{{cite web |last=Erdbrink |first=Thomas |title=Ayatollah Khamenei, Backing Iran Negotiators, Endorses Nuclear Deal |website=The New York Times |date=2015-07-16 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/19/world/middleeast/ayatollah-ali-khamenei-of-iran-backs-negotiators-and-doesnt-criticize-nuclear-deal.html |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
Hardliners are against the deal for a variety of the reasons, notably their desire to turn Iran into a nuclear armed state in order to deter the [[United States]] and [[Israel]], its violations of the [[Ali Khamenei|Ayatollah Khamenei]]'s red lines, and their belief that international inspections are a front for American intelligence-gathering.<ref name="Milans McFaul 2015">{{cite web |last=Milani |first=Abbas |last2=McFaul |first2=Michael |title=What Do Iranians Think of the Iran Deal? |website=The Atlantic |date=2015-08-11 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/08/iran-deal-politics-rouhani-khamenei/400985/ |access-date=2018-01-20}}</ref> Unofficially, members of the Revolutionary Guard worry that opening Iran up to global trade with the removal of sanctions will impede the organization's profits. The Revolutionary Guard Corps is believed to control a third of Iran's economy, a staggeringly high figure that could be reduced with more international commerce.<ref name="Gregory 2010">{{cite web |last=Gregory |first=Mark |title=Iran's Revolutionary Guards and their business empire |publisher=BBC News |date=2010-07-26 |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-10743580 |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Economic liberalization brought on by the deal could loosen the IRGC's control of the economy and lead to fresh resentment within the organization. In addition, the removal of U.S. sanctions also denies the Guard Corps from using the United States, or the West for that matter, as a propaganda tool and scapegoat for Iran's domestic problems.<ref name="Milani McFaul 2015">{{cite web |last=Milani |first=Abbas |last2=McFaul |first2=Michael |title=What Do Iranians Think of the Iran Deal? |website=The Atlantic |date=2015-08-11 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2015/08/iran-deal-politics-rouhani-khamenei/400985/ |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
One of the most prominent opponents of the JCPOA in Iran is former [[Supreme National Security Council|Secretary of the Supreme National Security Council]] [[Saeed Jalili]] who lambasted the deal and its negotiators for having offered too many concessions to American negotiators.<ref name="akarami">{{cite web |author=akarami |title=Former Iran deal negotiator slams concessions in nuclear deal |website=Al-Monitor |url=https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/ru/originals/2015/09/jalili-jcpoa-nuclear-concessions.html |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Jalili claimed the nuclear deal “violated Iran's independence and national sovereignty.”<ref name="Rezaei2017">{{cite book|author=Farhad Rezaei|title=Iran’s Nuclear Program: A Study in Proliferation and Rollback|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YJLZDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA230|date=5 January 2017|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-3-319-44120-7|pages=230–}}</ref>
Media in Iran is also divided on partisan lines as well, with conservative newspapers such as the ''[[Kayhan]]'' newspaper and ''[[Ettelaat]]'' newspaper publishing articles that opposed the deal.<ref name="Kangarlou 2015">{{cite web |last=Kangarlou |first=Tara |title=Tehran’s Nuclear Pact Debate Mirrors Washington's |website=Al Jazeera America |date=2015-08-13 |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2015/8/13/why-tehrans-debate-over-nuclear-pact-mirrors-washingtons.html |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
In many ways, the battle over the [[JCPOA]] is a [[Proxy fight|proxy conflict]] in the overarching debate over the future of Iran. The factions of the Iranian political spectrum who support the deal are the same faction who support [[globalization]], less religious influence in government, and a moderate [[foreign policy]] while those who oppose the deal are the same faction that advocate for a more religiously conservative society, the "[[Resistive economy|resistance economy]]", and more military intervention abroad.<ref name="Milani McFaul 2015" /> Nevertheless, the Iranian parliament approved the Iran deal 161-59-13 sending it to the [[Guardian Council]] which passed it with a "strong majority".<ref>Iran's Guardian Council passes nuclear bill into law https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-nuclear-law/irans-guardian-council-passes-nuclear-bill-into-law-idUSKCN0S81OW20151014</ref>
===Challenges to the JCPOA=== [[File:Ali Khamenei with the Revolutionary Guard Corps and Basij - Mashhad (52).jpg|thumbnail|right|Ali Khamenei with members of the Revolutionary Guard Corps.]] Outside of conservative political backlash there still remains a great litany of economic, social, and military challenges to the implementation of the Iran nuclear deal within [[Iran]] itself. Much of the popular support for the Iran deal comes from the public's perception of economic upsurges as a result of the sanctions relief brought on by the [[JCPOA]]. If the [[Economy of Iran|Iranian economy]] continues to remain stagnated, and foreign investment remains low, it is likely the public will turn away from the nuclear deal since it did not bring the level of economic relief that many Iranians banked their support of the deal on. This is evidenced by the 13% drop in approval of the deal among Iranians in the year after the deal was reached.<ref name="The Iran Primer 2016">{{cite web |title=Poll 1: Iranian Views on Nuclear Deal |website=The Iran Primer |date=2016-07-13 |url=http://iranprimer.usip.org/blog/2016/jul/14/poll-1-iranian-views-nuclear-deal |access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Even after the implementation of the JCPOA many foreign investors have remained weary of Iran. Decades of global economic isolation have strengthened the "economy of resistance", or the self-sufficient economy developed under sanctions, and as a result many businesses are actually front companies for or directly linked to the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps]]. Other aspects that have hampered [[foreign direct investment]] in the wake of the Iran deal include high levels of corruption and the arrest of foreigners suspected of [[espionage]]. Insufficient economic growth will almost assuredly impede the reformist presidency of [[Hassan Rouhani]] and lead to conservative gains that can further impede the [[JCPOA]].<ref>Challenges to the Nuclear Deal: The Economy https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/perspectives/PE200/PE218/RAND_PE218.pdf</ref>
Iran's increasing military involvement in the [[Middle East]] may also present a challenge to the deal. The regional conflict between [[Sunni]] and [[Shiite]] proxy groups aggravates tensions between the region's powers and motivates Iran to "demonstrate its resolve" for the purpose of domestic audiences. The conflicts that arise as a result can lead to greater confrontation between the [[United States]] and [[Iran]] which can undermine the deal.<ref>Challenges to the Nuclear Deal: Geopolitics https://www.rand.org/content/dam/rand/pubs/perspectives/PE200/PE218/RAND_PE218.pdf</ref>
==Opposition in the United States==
===Political opposition===
The Iran deal was met with almost unanimous derision and denunciation by [[conservatism in the United States|conservatives in the United States]]. Within days of the finalization of the deal, all [[Republican Party presidential candidates, 2016|Republican Party candidates for president in the 2016 election]] had issued a public statement criticizing the deal in one form or another. [[U.S. Senator]] from [[South Carolina]] and Republican candidate, [[Lindsey Graham]] called it a, "terrible deal" and a "death sentence for [[Israel]]."<ref name="Lindsey Graham: Press Release 2015">{{cite web | title=First to Weight In: Graham: | website=Lindsey Graham: Press Release | date=2015-07-16 | url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=112098 | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> A statement from former [[Governor of Florida|Florida governor]] [[Jeb Bush]] said, "The nuclear agreement announced by the Obama administration today is a dangerous, deeply flawed, and short sighted deal." [[Ben Carson]] called it a "historic mistake" while former [[Governor of Arkansas|Arkansas governor]] [[Mike Huckabee]] lambasted [[John Kerry]] for not standing strongly enough with [[Israel]]. [[Governor of New Jersey|New Jersey governor]] [[Chris Christie]] said "The deal threatens Israel, it threatens the [[United States]], and it turns 70 years of nuclear policy on its head."<ref name="LoBianco Tatum 2015">{{cite web | last=LoBianco | first=Tom | last2=Tatum | first2=Sophie | title=GOP 2016 hopefuls slam Iran nuclear deal - CNNPolitics | website=CNN | date=2015-07-14 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/14/politics/2016-candidates-iran-deal/index.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
In the [[United States Congress]], disparagement was equally fierce. [[Speaker of the House]] [[John Boehner]] told reporters in a briefing he thought it was a “bad deal” but added he did not have all the details so he couldn't make a definitive statement.<ref name="Editorial 2015">{{cite web | last=Editorial | first=Reuters | title=U.S. House Speaker Boehner says Iran accord looks like a 'bad deal' | website=U.S. | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/iran-nuclear-boehner-deal/u-s-house-speaker-boehner-says-iran-accord-looks-like-a-bad-deal-idUSL2N0ZU13820150714 | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> Boehner later said he would "do everything" in his power to block the deal.<ref name="Walsh Barrett 2015">{{cite web | last=Walsh | first=Deirdre | last2=Barrett | first2=Ted | title=Boehner vows to 'do everything' to block Iran deal - CNNPolitics | website=CNN | date=2015-07-22 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/07/22/politics/john-boehner-iran-deal-nuclear/index.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> The [[U.S. Senate Majority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]] accused the Obama administration of approaching the talks with a "flawed perspective" that prioritized Iran's interests over the "national goal" of [[Iran and weapons of mass destruction|Iranian nuclear disarmament]].<ref name="ABC News Radio 2011">{{cite web | title=McConnell: Iran Deal a Result of 'Flawed Perspective' - Politics News | website=ABC News Radio | date=2011-05-12 | url=http://abcnewsradioonline.com/politics-news/mcconnell-iran-deal-a-result-of-flawed-perspective.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
[[Bob Corker]], U.S. Senator from [[Tennessee]] and chairman of the [[Senate Foreign Relations Committee]] claimed it offered too many concessions to Iran and echoed other Republican leaders in describing it as counterproductive.<ref name="USA TODAY 2015">{{cite web | title=Corker warns of 'breathtaking' concessions on Iran deal | website=USA TODAY | date=2015-06-15 | url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2015/06/15/corker-says-back-away-from-iran-deal/71260448/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> [[Richard Burr]], U.S. Senator from [[North Carolina]] and chairman of the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] called it "dangerously limited" and criticized [[President Obama]] for "mischaracterizing" the threat Iran poses to the United States.<ref name="U.S. Senator Richard Burr of North Carolina 2015">{{cite web | title=Burr on Iran Deal: American People Aren’t Buying Into Bad Deal | website=U.S. Senator Richard Burr of North Carolina | date=2015-08-05 | url=https://www.burr.senate.gov/press/releases/burr-on-iran-deal-american-people-arent-buying-into-bad-deal- | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
Representative [[Louie Gohmert]] of [[Texas's 1st congressional district]], who called the Iran deal a "move towards a [[nuclear holocaust]]",<ref name="Talking Points Memo 2015">{{cite web | title=Gohmert Vows To Quit Congress And Await 'Nuclear Holocaust' If Iran Deal Passes | website=Talking Points Memo | date=2015-09-09 | url=https://talkingpointsmemo.com/livewire/louie-gohmert-glenn-beck-iran | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> introduced a resolution into the [[U.S. House of Representatives]] that would classify the Iran nuclear deal as a [[treaty]] which, if passed, would require the Senate to vote on it. As it stands the Iran deal was made as an [[executive agreement]]. Gohmert said he would leave Congress if the resolution was passed.<ref name="Louie Gohmert 2015">{{cite web | title=Gohmert Introduces Resolution to Declare Iran Deal a Treaty and Offers Not to Run ONLY IF the Constitution is Followed Regarding the Iran Treaty | website=Louie Gohmert | date=2015-09-09 | url=https://gohmert.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=398247 | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> Representative [[Steve King]] of [[Iowa's 4th congressional district]], said in a [[Fox News]] interview that the deal “means tens of millions of lives down the road.”<ref name="Mullen 2015">{{cite web | last=Mullen | first=Tom | title=Iran is Giving up Far More Than the United States in Nuclear Deal | website=HuffPost | date=2015-09-10 | url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/tom-mullen/iran-is-giving-up-far-mor_b_8118292.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
[[File:Tea Party Patriots Stop the Iran Nuclear Deal IMG 4628 (21293537052).jpg|thumbnail|right|Senator [[Ted Cruz]] delivers a speech before protesters denouncing the Iran nuclear deal.]]
A [[Stop Iran Rally|rally]] organized in July 2015 by Jeffrey Wiesenfeld, an investment management principal and child of [[Holocaust]] survivors, drew thousands of people to [[Times Square]] in [[New York City]] to protest the Iran deal. The crowd which numbered in the thousands chanted "Kill the deal!" and "Where is Chuck?" (in reference to Senator [[Chuck Schumer]]) and saw bipartisan speakers including [[George Pataki]] and [[Alan Dershowitz]].<ref name="the Guardian 2015">{{cite web | title=Thousands pack New York’s Times Square to protest Iran nuclear deal with US | website=the Guardian | date=2015-07-23 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jul/23/thousands-pack-times-square-protest-iran-nuclear-deal-us | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
In September 2015, Republican congressional leaders organized a [[Tea Party movement|Tea Party]] rally on the [[U.S. Capitol|Capitol]] lawn to protest the terms of the [[JCPOA]]. For several hours hundreds of protesters voiced their opposition to the bill. Then-presidential candidate [[Donald Trump]] headlined the rally alongside Senator [[Ted Cruz]]. Trump spoke against the deal saying he had never seen a deal as "incompetently negotiated" as the Iranian nuclear deal. Other speakers included former [[Governor of Alaska|Alaska governor]] [[Sarah Palin]] who similarly voiced opposition to the deal.<ref name="Stokolz Gass 2017">{{cite web | last=Stokols | first=Eli | last2=Gass | first2=Nick | title=Trump storms Washington | website=POLITICO | date=2017-12-15 | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2015/09/donald-trump-iran-deal-washington-rally-213451 | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref><ref name="D dies in D 2015">{{cite web | title=Donald Trump, Ted Cruz headline Capitol rally against Iran nuclear deal | website=Washington Post | date=2015-09-09 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/09/09/donald-trump-ted-cruz-to-headline-capitol-rally-against-iran-nuclear-deal/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
On the contrary, [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] widely praised the deal with Democratic candidate and former [[Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] releasing a statement announcing her support for the deal, "I support the agreement because it can help us prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon. With vigorous enforcement, unyielding verification, and swift consequences for any violations, this agreement can make the United States, Israel, and our [[Arab]] partners safer," and, "we should applaud President Obama, [[John Kerry|Secretary Kerry]], and [[Ernest Moniz|Secretary Moniz]] for getting this done, and proceed with wisdom and strength in enforcing this deal to the fullest and in meeting the broader Iranian challenge."<ref name="Yglesias 2015">{{cite web | last=Yglesias | first=Matthew | title=Hillary Clinton makes the case for Obama's Iran nuclear deal | website=Vox | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://www.vox.com/2015/7/14/8966945/hillary-clinton-statement-iran-deal | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> [[Vermont]] Senator [[Bernie Sanders]] also supported the deal in order to "give peace a chance."<ref name="BernieHippie 2015">{{cite web | title=Bernie Sanders defends Iran nuclear deal | website=Washington Post | date=2015-08-09 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2015/08/09/bernie-sanders-defends-iran-nuclear-deal/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> However, [[Jim Webb]] former Democratic senator from [[Virginia]] and [[Secretary of the Navy]] broke from other Democratic candidates, telling [[National Public Radio]] that he was skeptical of removing sanctions and believed that the U.S. had tacitly acknowledged that Iran will develop a nuclear weapon.<ref name="Gass 2015">{{cite web | last=Gass | first=Nick | title=Webb breaks from 2016 Dems in dinging Iran deal | website=POLITICO | date=2015-07-15 | url=https://www.politico.com/story/2015/07/jim-webb-criticize-iran-deal-120145.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
The [[American Israel Public Affairs Committee]], Washington D.C. based pro-Israel [[501(c) organization|501(c)(4) organization]], purchased more than $25 million in television advertising to assail the deal and began a campaign of lobbying congressman in its effort to scrap the [[JCPOA]]. Alongside its subsidiary group, Citizens for a Nuclear Free Iran, AIPAC's lobbying barrage targeted undecided Democratic politicians.<ref name="Davis 2015">{{cite web | last=Davis | first=Julie Hirschfeld | title=It’s Either Iran Nuclear Deal or ‘Some Form of War,’ Obama Warns | website=The New York Times | date=2015-08-05 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/us/politics/obama-urges-critics-of-iran-deal-to-ignore-drumbeat-of-war.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref><ref name="NPR.org 2015">{{cite web | title=Lobbyists Spending Millions To Sway The Undecided On Iran Deal | website=NPR.org | date=2015-08-06 | url=https://www.npr.org/sections/itsallpolitics/2015/08/06/429911872/in-iran-deal-fight-lobbyists-are-spending-millions-to-sway-12-senators | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
===Polling===
A [[Cable News Network|CNN]]/[[Opinion Research Corporation|ORC]] poll conducted in mid-August 2015 showed that 52% of American registered voters believe Congress should reject the [[JCPOA]]<ref name="Agiesta Diamond 2015">{{cite web | last=Agiesta | first=Jennifer | last2=Diamond | first2=Jeremy | title=Poll: Most Americans want Congress to reject Iran deal | website=CNN | date=2015-08-20 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/20/politics/iran-deal-poll-majority-americans-disapprove/index.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> while a poll by [[Pew Research Center]] in September showed that only 21% of its respondents supported the deal while the rest either opposed it or offered no opinion.<ref name="Pew Research Center for the People and the Press 2015">{{cite web | title=Support for Iran Nuclear Agreement Falls | website=Pew Research Center for the People and the Press | date=2015-09-08 | url=http://www.people-press.org/2015/09/08/support-for-iran-nuclear-agreement-falls/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> However that same month the [[University of Maryland]] held a panel which featured expert-vetted arguments on both sides of the issue and found that after weighing all options, only 45% of respondents opposed the deal.<ref name="UMD Right Now :: University of Maryland 2015">{{cite web | title=UMD Study Finds that After Weighing Options, a Majority of Americans Approve Iran Nuclear Deal | website=UMD Right Now :: University of Maryland | date=2015-09-02 | url=https://www.umdrightnow.umd.edu/news/umd-study-finds-after-weighing-options-majority-americans-approve-iran-nuclear-deal | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> A poll conducted on behalf of the [[American Jewish Committee]] found that 47% of American Jews disapprove of the deal, with only a narrow majority supporting it.<ref name="JTA 2015">{{cite web | author=JTA | title=Jews Back Iran Deal by Narrow Margin, Poll Says | website=The Forward | date=2015-09-11 | url=https://forward.com/news/breaking-news/320816/jews-back-iran-deal-by-narrow-margin-poll-says/ | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> A poll of [[Iranian-Americans]] found that 8 in 10 believed the agreement would improve ties between the [[United States]] and [[Iran]].<ref name="paaia.org 2015">{{cite web | title=PAAIA Releases National Public Opinion Survey of Iranian Americans & the American Public - PAAIA | website=paaia.org | date=2015-08-12 | url=http://www.paaia.org/CMS/paaia-releases-national-public-opinion-survey-of-iranian-americans-american-public.aspx | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150812183300/http://www.paaia.org/CMS/paaia-releases-national-public-opinion-survey-of-iranian-americans-american-public.aspx | archive-date=2015-08-12 | dead-url=yes | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> A CNN/ORC poll administered in October 2017 on the Iran deal showed that 67% of American respondents wanted to remain in the deal.<ref name="Struyk 2017">{{cite web | last=Struyk | first=Ryan | title=CNN poll: Two-thirds want to stay in Iran nuclear deal | website=CNN | date=2017-10-20 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/20/politics/poll-trump-iran-deal-north-korea/index.html | access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref>
===Experts=== William H. Tobey, a senior fellow in [[Harvard University|Harvard's]] [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]] expressed his opposition to the deal saying that Iran gave too few concessions in return for too much sanctions relief and that the deal was simply postponing Iran's development of a [[nuclear weapon]] rather than halting it, calling the deal a mere "speed bump" in the country's path to being nuclear armed.<ref name="Mecklin 2015">{{cite web | last=Mecklin | first=John | title=The experts assess the Iran agreement of 2015 | website=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://thebulletin.org/experts-assess-iran-agreement-20158507 | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> An editorial written by former [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] analyst and vice president of the [[Center for Security Policy]], a [[Washington D.C.]] based [[conservative]] think tank, Frederick H. Fleitz, claimed that the deal was made at the expense of the United States and called it "not a verifiable agreement". Fleitz argued that since the [[IAEA]] only had non-negotiable access to declared nuclear sites and not military or missile facilities, the deal was toothless, and Iran could easily develop a nuclear weapon under the nose of international inspectors.<ref name="Fleitz 2015">{{cite web | last=Fleitz | first=Fred | title=Iran nuclear deal much worse than experts predicted | website=Fox News | date=2015-07-14 | url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2015/07/14/iran-nuclear-deal-much-worse-than-experts-predicted.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> [[James S. Robbins]], a senior fellow in the [[American Foreign Policy Council]] called the deal "impotent" in an editorial in [[US News & World Report]] due to the fact it does little to hamper Iran's missile programs.<ref name="Robbins 2016">{{cite web | last=Robbins | first=James S. | title=Iran Shoots a Hole in the Nuclear Deal | website=US News & World Report | date=2016-03-15 | url=https://www.usnews.com/opinion/blogs/world-report/articles/2016-03-15/iran-missile-test-reveals-weakness-of-nuclear-deal | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
In August 2015, a letter signed by 190 former generals and admirals was sent to Congressional leaders expressing opposition to the bill. The letter argued that the deal put too many limitations on IAEA access to Iranian sites, would provide Iran with $150 billion in sanctions relief much of which would surely go funding [[Iran and state-sponsored terrorism|Iranian proxy groups]] in the Middle East, and offered too few concessions from [[Iran]]. American national security, the five paragraph letter argued, would be put at risk if the deal was not rejected.<ref name="Washington Post 2015">{{cite web | title=Read: An open letter from retired generals and admirals opposing the Iran nuclear deal | website=Washington Post | date=2015-07-14 | url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/documents/world/read-an-open-letter-from-retired-generals-and-admirals-opposing-the-iran-nuclear-deal/1703/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Some of the signers of the letter included [[Robert J. Kelly]], former commander-in-chief of the [[United States Pacific Fleet]], [[William G. Boykin]], former Deputy [[Undersecretary of Defense for Intelligence]], Joseph Hoar, former commander of [[U.S. Central Command]], and Joe Sestak, former Navy vice admiral and Director for Defense on the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] under [[Bill Clinton]], among others. The letter was made in response to a letter signed by 36 generals and admirals praising the deal.<ref name="Washington Post 2012">{{cite web | title=Read: An open letter from retired generals and admirals on the Iran nuclear deal | website=Washington Post | date=2012-06-07 | url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/documents/world/read-an-open-letter-from-retired-generals-and-admirals-on-the-iran-nuclear-deal/1689/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> In response to both letters, former [[U.S. Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] general [[Anthony Zinni]] said "I'm convinced that 90% of the guys who signed the letter one way or the other don't have any clue about whether it's a good or bad deal. They sign it because somebody's asked them to sign it."<ref name="Thompson 2015">{{cite web | last=Thompson | first=Mark | title=Retired Generals Wage Letter War Over Iran Nuclear-Deal Vote | website=Time | date=2015-08-27 | url=http://time.com/4013966/iran-nuclear-vote-generals/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
===Trump Administration=== The [[Presidency of Donald Trump|Trump Administration]] has characterized Iran as an adversary of the United States on numerous occasions and has been critical of the regime in [[Tehran]] and the Iran nuclear deal. Over the course of the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 election]], [[Donald Trump]] repeatedly attacked the deal. During a speech to the pro-Israel lobbying group AIPAC he said dismantling the Iranian nuclear deal was his first priority.<ref name="Begleyz 2016">{{cite web | last=Begley | first=Sarah | title=Read Donald Trump's Speech to AIPAC | website=Time | date=2016-03-21 | url=http://time.com/4267058/donald-trump-aipac-speech-transcript/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> During a presidential debate he described it as a "horrible deal".<ref name="Washington Postzz 2016">{{cite web | title=The first Trump-Clinton presidential debate transcript, annotated | website=Washington Post | date=2016-09-26 | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/09/26/the-first-trump-clinton-presidential-debate-transcript-annotated/ | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
After assuming office, Trump administration [[National Security Adviser]] [[Michael Flynn]] placed Iran “officially on notice” during a February 1 press conference.<ref name="NPR.org 2017">{{cite web | title=Flynn Puts Iran On Notice After Ballistic Missile Test | website=NPR.org | date=2017-02-02 | url=https://www.npr.org/2017/02/02/512998437/flynn-puts-iran-on-notice-after-ballistic-missile-test | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> However, the Trump administration shied away from outright dismantling the deal. Instead, in April 2017 it commenced a "policy review" during which time it announced it would continue to implement the [[JCPOA]]. The administration has continued to recertify the Iran deal despite President Trump's previous objections, most likely bowing to pressure from cabinet members [[Secretary of State]] [[Rex Tillerson]] and [[Secretary of Defense]] [[James Mattis]] who are proponents of the deal.<ref name="Savransky 2017">{{cite web | last=Savransky | first=Rebecca | title=Tillerson: Staying in the Iran deal in best interest of the US | website=TheHill | date=2017-10-15 | url=http://thehill.com/policy/international/355508-tillerson-staying-in-the-iran-deal-in-best-interest-of-the-us | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref><ref name="Starr Cohen Browne 2017">{{cite web | last=Starr | first=Barbara | last2=Cohen | first2=Zachary | last3=Browne | first3=Ryan | title=Mattis: US should stay in Iran deal | website=CNN | date=2017-10-03 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/03/politics/mattis-iran-nuclear-deal-national-security/index.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref><ref name="Al Jazeera 2018">{{cite web | title=Trump waives Iran nuclear sanctions 'for last time' | website=Al Jazeera | date=2018-01-12 | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/01/trump-waives-iran-nuclear-sanctions-time-180112164307626.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> However, National Security Adviser [[H.R. McMaster]] has called the Iran deal "fundamentally flawed", and added the "incompleteness" of the deal "could give the regime cover to advance a nuclear program."<ref name="Diaz 2017">{{cite web | last=Diaz | first=Daniella | title=McMaster: Iran deal 'fundamentally flawed' | website=CNN | date=2017-09-21 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/09/21/politics/h-r-mcmaster-donald-trump-iran-deal-white-house/index.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> In October 2017, McMaster invited a group of [[Democratic Caucus of the United States Senate|Democratic senators]] to the [[White House]] for a policy discussion on the deal. Those in the meeting reported that they felt as if the purpose of the discussion was to give McMaster talking points in his attempt to persuade President Trump to remain in the deal.<ref name="Bashaa 2017">{{cite web | last=Bash | first=Dana | title=Senate Dems sense McMaster not sold on decertifying Iran deal | website=CNN | date=2017-10-05 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/05/politics/hr-mcmaster-iran-deal/index.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> On 12 January 2018, [[Donald Trump|President Trump]] issued another waiver of sanctions on Iran saying this was "to secure our European allies' agreement to fix the terrible flaws of the Iran nuclear deal."<ref name="Diamondzz 2018">{{cite web | last=Diamond | first=Jeremy | title=Trump issues warning, but continues to honor Iran deal | website=CNN | date=2018-01-12 | url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/politics/president-donald-trump-iran-deal-waiver/index.html | access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>

The '''DEMO conference''' is a series of technology-focused [[business conference]]s in which pre-selected companies and entrepreneurs launch new products and services.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/technology/applications/desktop/news/index.cfm?newsid=19514 |title=Computerworlduk.com |publisher=Computerworlduk.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |accessdate=2010-03-01 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/columnist/edwardbaig/2008-01-30-demo-tech_N.htm |title=Demo conference intrigues, but doesn't electrify |work=USA Today |date=2008-01-31 |author=Baig, Edward C. }}</ref> Produced by [[International Data Group|IDG]], DEMO seeks to identify and promote new technology with the potential to solve big problems with careful selection and coaching. Products launched at DEMO include: [[Salesforce.com]], [[TiVo]], [[VMware]], [[Evernote]], [[E*Trade]], [[WebEx]] and [[Fusion-io]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demo.com/successstories.html |title=Demo.com |publisher=Demo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> DEMO Conferences are held under the names DEMO Enterprise, DEMO Africa, DEMO China, DEMO Brazil, DEMO Asia (Vietnam), DEMO Europe (Russia), DEMO Tour, and DEMO Fall.<ref>http://www.eiseverywhere.com/ehome/DEMO/events/</ref>
In 1990, [[Stewart Alsop II]] realized he was more intrigued by the one-on-one demonstrations of coming technologies conducted in hallways and hotel rooms during the off hours during technology conferences.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2001/02/15/technology/state-of-the-art-onstage-digital-hits-and-misses.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm</ref> This prompted Alsop to found the first DEMO Conference in 1991.
The conference draws media attention for its emerging technologies.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/technologylive/post/2010/03/demo-tech-conference-what-to-watch-for/1 | work=USA Today | title=Demo tech conference: What to watch for | date=2010-03-22}}</ref> At the DEMOSpring 2010 Conference, media attendees included [[Business Week]], [[CBS]], [[Forbes]], [[LA Times]], [[Popular Science]], [[USA Today]], and [[The Wall Street Journal]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.demo.com/attend/whoattends.html |title=Demo.com |publisher=Demo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> Entrepreneurs launching their products and services often cite publicity as a reason for choosing to pitch at DEMO.<ref>http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/25/should-start-ups-pay-to-pitch/</ref> Additional conference attendees include venture capitalists, angels and other investors, corporate development officers, and entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kpsplocal2.com/news/local/story/demo-conference-technology-unveil/cZ3tBfM12kuD3ur-aC7xlA.cspx |title=Kpsplocal12.com |publisher=Kpsplocal2.com |date=2010-03-22 |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721155439/http://www.kpsplocal2.com/news/local/story/demo-conference-technology-unveil/cZ3tBfM12kuD3ur-aC7xlA.cspx |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref>
DEMO Conferences also feature prominent entrepreneurs and technology professionals as speakers and panelists at each event. Previous speakers include <ref>https://venturebeat.com/2010/09/13/demos-next-wave-of-innovation-heres-the-launch-list/?dbk</ref> Twitter cofounder and Square CEO [[Jack Dorsey]], SAP CEO [[Bill McDermott]], LinkedIn CEO [[Jeff Weiner]], Hewlett-Packard CTO Phil McKinney, and Google Enterprise President Dave Girouard.
==DEMO Enterprise== The DEMO Enterprise event highlights enterprise products gaining significant traction in the market, as well as a first glimpse at startling product prototypes still under development. Technologies from cloud computing, mobile, and big data to sensor networks, 3D printing, and robotics are introduced to the competitive landscape for enterprise large and small.
The DEMO Enterprise event highlights enterprise products gaining significant traction in the market, as well as a first glimpse at product prototypes still under development. Technologies from remote healthcare,<ref>https://venturebeat.com/2013/10/17/google-glass-in-the-or-theres-an-app-for-that-but-would-you-trust-it-with-your-spleen/</ref> cloud computing, mobile, and big data to sensor networks, 3D printing, and robotics are introduced to the competitive landscape for enterprise.
25 percent of the products launched at DEMO 2004 were acquired, and 20 percent were acquired from DEMO 2005. These companies include:<ref>http://www.eiseverywhere.com/ehome/29414/launch/success-stories</ref> *[[Half.com]] ([[eBay]]) *[[Picasa]] ([[Google]]) *[[IronPort]] ([[Cisco]]) *[[Serious Magic]] ([[Adobe Systems|Adobe]]) *[[Stata Labs]] ([[Yahoo]]) *[[Danger, Inc.]] ([[Microsoft]])
